speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I would like to prepare the coffee for you?"

speaker: Marion
text: "Je voudrais préparer le café pour vous."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I would like to prepare roast beef for dinner?" Or as the French would say, "I would like to prepare the roast beef for the dinner."

speaker: Marion
text: "Je voudrais préparer le rosbeef pour le dîner."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How about, "I would like to reserve a table?"

speaker: Marion
text: "Je voudrais réserver une table."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "I would like to reserve a table for dinner."

speaker: Marion
text: "Je voudrais réserver une table pour le dîner."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now again, make sure when you say "for dinner" in French that you say "for the dinner."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Because the French will always say, "for the dinner." They will never just say, "for dinner," which would be-

speaker: Marion
text: "Pour dîner"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: But rather they will say, "for the dinner," which is?

speaker: Marion
text: "Pour le dîner."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, we've obviously encountered some words in English that are... That we can use in French very easily such as the words that end in I-O-N. Um, words like "table" that end in A-B-L-E, and their cousins, the words that end in I-B-L-E.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: But there are actually many, many thousands of words and they're easy to identify by the word endings. For instance, let's have a look at a very simple word in English. Let's take the word "room" in English.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, is "room" a long or a short word?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And does it sound Germanic or French? Perhaps you don't know at this stage.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: As I mentioned at the beginning, the short words in English tend to be of Germanic Anglo-Saxon origin. So, a word like "room" is more likely than not to have come from the Germanic part of the language.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So, if we want to find what the word for "room" is in French we can look in other areas of English and see if there's an alternative, perhaps a longer word. Perhaps it's not used as much. But we can use tricks like this to find vocabulary.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And as I've often said to people before, it's much easier [laughs] to invent vocabulary than to memorize it. If you can invent it, you can invent thousands of words. If you memorize, it takes weeks to learn a hundred. Um, now let's think about those words we do have for "room" in English. For instance, we can say "bedroom" in English but there's also a more old-fashioned way to refer to the bedroom. Perhaps you can think of an example.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: If you're not able to get it by yourself, I'll give you some help.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: For instance, perhaps, um, even now one t- talks about something like the "queen's bed chamber," rather than the "queen's bedroom."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And so, we also have the word "chamber," that means for "room," rather than simply using "room." We use it less often but it does exist in English. Again, as I've ti- as I've said, typically short words are Germanic, longer words are French. So, we have "chamber" in English.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, this leads us to another useful rule. Words that end in "-amber" in English

speaker: Paul Noble
text: generally exist in French, except the "amber" becomes?

speaker: Marion
text: "Ambre."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And actually the word for "amber" in French is?

speaker: Marion
text: "Ambre."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: With that in mind, how do you think you would say "chamber" in French?

speaker: Marion
text: "Chambre."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: You'll notice also that the ch-

speaker: Paul Noble
text: is pronounced sh- in French, as you may have already said. So again, "chamber" in French is?

speaker: Marion
text: "Chambre."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Which means "room."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: With that in mind, how would you say, "I would like to reserve a room?"

speaker: Marion
text: "Je voudrais réserver une chambre."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Or if you'd like you can simply say, "I would like a room," which would be?

speaker: Marion
text: "Je voudrais une chambre."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Good.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: A "person" in French is?

text: "Une personne."

text: The word for "two" in French is?

speaker: Marion
text: "Deux."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So, how do you think you would say "two people" in French? Literally, "two persons."

speaker: Marion
text: "Deux personnes."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Again, you'll notice that even though there's two of them we don't make the sound of an S at the end. "One person" is?

speaker: Marion
text: "Une personne."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And "two people" in French are?

speaker: Marion
text: "Deux personnes."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, in the French there is an S at the end, but remember, in French we don't pronounce the consonant at the end of a word unless it's in for luck. An S is not in for luck.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So, keeping in mind that "two people" in French, "two persons," are pronounced as-

speaker: Marion
text: "Deux personnes."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I would like a room for two people?"

text: So, to say "two nights" would be?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Again, make sure that when you say it you say, "I would like a room for two people for two nights." Let's do that one more time.

speaker: Marion
